text:
They leave the school together, strolling into the misty Gotham night side by side, just close enough that it doesn’t look supremely awkward. Peter lets out a quiet breath of relief when they finally leave the school. The conference is done. And no one died, miraculously. Somehow, Loki managed to charm all of his teachers with only a few careful words and managed the whole situation beautifully. Peter didn’t even have to fling himself out of the nearest window and flee into the night, never to be seen again. Minus that one hiccup with Tim and Duke’s brother, the evening passed without incident. Mission success.

“You should worry about what you promised him,” Fury says.

Okay, yeah, fine, but one crisis at a time, okay?

Loki pauses on the sidewalk outside of the school and turns to face Peter, reaching out to grip his shoulder. Peter, pale and shaky from a wicked combination of exhaustion, his growing migraine, and hunger pangs, frowns up at him. This isn’t anywhere close to where they agreed to pull their disappearing act.

“Listen, kid,” he sas, pitching his voice just a bit too loud. Peter catches sight of Tim and Dick from the corner of his eye and realizes that Loki wants them to overhear this. Something icy grips his stomach and he’s suddenly worried about whatever Loki’s going to pull. “This isn’t working out.”

Peter stares at him. “What?”

“This whole ‘us’ thing. You and me, you know,” Loki says, pointing to himself and then Peter. “Don’t get me wrong, it’s been great--you’re a brilliant kid, all your teachers love you--but, uh, I’m not really built for this.”

Peter’s headache is getting worse. His temples throb, and his vision begins to go blurry at the edges. He sighs, exhausted. “What are you--”

“So I’m cutting you off. You’ve been handling things on your own long enough that you’ve got this all figured out anyway, so it won’t be that much of a change.”

“Cutting me off,” Peter repeats slowly. His blood is pounding in his ears; a sign of his worsening migraine. He raises his own voice, just to hear himself over it. “Cutting me off from what? This is the first time you’ve done anything for me since we came to Gotham--”

“You were supposed to be getting an allowance. You didn’t get any of that? Huh. There must have been a problem at the bank,” Loki says. He gives Peter an easy grin and gently punches his shoulder. It’s unbelievably awkward, and Peter steps away from him on instinct. “Even better! You’re already fully independent. See, I knew you had this.”

Peter stares at him for a long, silent moment that seems to drag on forever before saying, simply, “What.”

“Guess you’re not getting it,” Loki says. His tone grows firmer, and just a bit sharper; not quite a yell, but he is projecting his voice. “We’re through. I’m going to go my way, and you go your way.”

And then it clicks for Peter. Loki used him. The runes he traced out earlier severed him from whatever prison he was in. He’s free of the Soul Stone, free of being trapped with the others. Peter just set the God of Mischief loose in this universe, free to do whatever he pleases. The gravity of the situation hits him fully then, and Peter pales. “No, no, you can’t--”

“I just did,” Loki says from behind Tony’s face, adjusting his cufflinks. “But hey, once you graduate, look me up in New York.” He winks, and his grin grows sharper. “I was serious about that job offer, and I’d love to catch up with you in a few years.”

“Son of a bitch,” Sam says quietly. “He played us.”

“You can’t just--” Peter steps towards him, and then comes to an abrupt stop. Every nerve in his head flares up as if struck by lightning, and he’s momentarily dazzled by a white hot pain stabbing the back of his eyes like railroad spikes.

“Another migraine? Really? You should get that looked at. Maybe eat a little more,” Loki says casually. He checks his watch. “Anyway, I have a flight to catch. Good luck, Peter. It’s been an experience.”

Peter realizes that there’s a subtle green to his migraine aura this time. Loki is causing the migraine; he probably started it back at the fire station. Loki turns to leave and Peter growls, marching after him. Another bright flash across his eyes causes him to stumble.

Warm arms catch him, steadying him. A quiet voice murmurs near him. Tim's brother, Dick. “It’s okay. We’ve got you.”

“I have to talk to--” Peter starts. He can’t finish the sentence. Another of those horrible flashes hit him. This time, it’s sharp enough to bring tears to his eyes. He can feel the arm around his shoulders tighten protectively.

“He’s already gone,” Dick says gently. “Come on. You can stay with us.”

“No, I--I need to--” Another flash. And Peter realizes that this was Loki’s plan. To get him here and then abandon him, making a scene of it, so Peter would be delayed by Tim, Duke, and their brother. He tries to struggle free of Dick’s grip, hastily wiping his eyes. He can’t manage it; the migraine is getting worse, and his balance hasn’t quite recovered. “I need to go after him--”

“Later,” Tim says, his tone soft and protective. He settles a pair of sunglasses over Peter’s eyes. “We’ll deal with him later.”

“Where’s Duke?” Dick asks Tim quietly.

“I sent him a text a minute ago. He’s getting the car,” Tim answers, just as quietly. It’s not quiet enough, not with Peter’s sensitive hearing. “Alfred’s getting the spare bedroom ready, too.”

“Good,” Dick says, relieved.

A car rolls up to the curb and god, he can hear every part of it. The engine, well maintained as it is, still has a near overpowering growl. The hazard lights click on, and there’s a weighted heat to the flashes when the light hits his skin. He can even hear the fuel rushing through the vehicle. Loki didn’t turn his senses up to eleven. He shot them up to an even one thousand. Peter sways on his feet, nearly pitching forward. Dick adjusts his hold across his shoulders and braces him before he can fall.

The door opens, and he’s carefully nudged inside. Someone buckles him in, like a child, and he’d be mortified and embarrassed if his head wasn’t threatening to explode from pain. Other doors open, shut, there’s murmured conversation he can’t hear because of that ever present screeching whine in his ears, and then the car is in motion. The ride passes mostly in silence.

Peter has half a mind to unbuckle himself, pop open the door, and then flee--

“No, stay here. If you jump out, you’ll just tear yourself up,” Bucky says flatly. “And if you try, we’ll get Duke to haul your dumb ass back in the car.”

Peter feels someone startle in the seat beside him. Whoever it is--Duke, he realizes, he recognizes him through the gloom and sunglasses now--reaches out to take his shoulder.

“Take it easy, man. Go back to sleep. We’re almost home,” he says, pitching his voice low.

He’d been asleep? When? Maybe after he was put into the car. It’s a smooth ride, and the window glass is cold and soothing. Peter slumps back against the door with a quiet grunt, drifting back off. He is sleeping. Or dozing, at least, like he did when he was working with Batman a couple of days ago. This time instead of the cold, it’s a vise grip burn of a migraine burrowing into his brain.

“What was that about?” Tim asks.

“I think he woke up and panicked,” Duke says after a moment. “Seems like he was about to jump out of the car and run?”

“Migraines can make you disoriented,” Dick says. “He probably didn’t recognize where he was.”

“Probably,” Duke says after a moment. “How much further?”

“Two minutes. Alfred is waiting for us,” Dick says.

Peter sleeps. This time, he doesn’t stir when the car stops. He’s vaguely aware of Duke gently pulling him away from the door and supporting him until Dick unbuckles him and lifts him up out of the car. He can feel the man grumble, shifting his hold as he carries Peter up a set of stairs. Peter tries to get up, to shift and move, but Dick keeps him braced against his chest with Peter’s head resting against his shoulder.

This is mortifying.

"No shame in letting people carry you when you need it," Sam says.

“He’s too light,” Dick says quietly.

“Yeah,” Tim says with a sigh. “He is.”

A prim, polite, and decidedly British voice speaks next. Peter doesn’t recognize it. “I’ve prepared the room across from yours, Master Richard.” A pause. “I’ll see to finding him more clothing, and food.”

“Thanks, Alfred,” Dick says. “That’ll put him between Tim and Duke’s room, too.”

“Have you informed Master Bruce yet?”

A very long pause follows that question. Finally, Tim clears his throat. “I’ll go make a phone call.”

“That would be wise, Master Tim,” Alfred says politely.

Peter drifts for a moment; it’s hard to focus on his surroundings when his head is throbbing. When he stirs again, he’s laying in a bed far too large and comfortable to belong to him. His headache has lessened, but hasn’t fully disappeared. His shoes are off, and he’s been tucked beneath blankets that are warm and soft. The curtains are drawn tight across the windows, and he can hear the gentle drumming of rain against the window. He can also hear three other heartbeats nearby, hidden in the dark.

That pushes him awake. He stirs, struggling to sit up. The pain in his head, which had settled to a dull roar, swells to an overpowering wave that paralyzes him before he can sit up. Loki’s spell, whatever it was, is still powerful enough to knock him flat on his back. He hisses in pain.

“Easy,” Wanda says gently. “It’s your friends. They’re staying close to you. You’re safe.”

Now that she mentions it, he can make out the vague outlines of Duke, Tim, and Dick in the room, asleep in chairs or, in Tim’s case, facedown on the floor. He stares at them for a moment, surprised, and then rubs his eyes, trying to sort out a rush of emotions that threaten to overwhelm him.

One floats through the mess, rising to the top. He’s going to kill Loki.

“That’s a thought for another day,” Wanda says before gently reaching out and tapping his forehead. The pain abates, and he starts to slip back into true sleep. “Rest.”

He sleeps for a long time.

* * *

* * *

He sleeps well into the next day. He only knows this based on half heard conversations from outside his door.

“It isn’t getting better,” Tim says, worried. “If anything it’s worse. How long do migraines last? Are they supposed to last this long?”

“I don’t know. I don’t get migraines, just headaches,” Duke says. He pauses. “I have an idea, hang on.”

The door to Peter’s room inches open, casting in gentle light from the hallway. Peter can hear Duke step inside; his heartbeat, steady and healthy, sounds like thundering drums in the dark. Peter risks peeking out from under the blanket.

“Sam, how do we help?” Duke whispers.

Something gold forms near Duke. Sam Wilson briefly becomes visible. “Bucky gets like this sometimes, too. He needs food. Soup, soft bread, electrolytes. And water. A ton of it.”

“Who’s Bucky?”

“Ask Peter about Germany sometime to find out,” Sam says. He starts to fade and hurries to add. “Peter's starving. He can’t heal without food. Make twice as much soup as you’d make for an entire family and make sure he eats all of it.”

“Yeah, got it,” Duke says. “Thanks.”

Sam disappears. Peter settles back into his burning migraine.

* * *

The smell of freshly made soup and bread cuts through his pain like a knife. The pain rolls back so suddenly that it’s almost disorienting. Alfred is in his room, carrying a bowl of steaming chicken broth and freshly made bread on a covered tray. Peter blinks awake, his head clearing for the first time since Loki manifested himself into reality. He sits up slowly, running one hand through sweat slick hair, squinting sleepily at the butler and the food. “He cast a curse with a very simple way to break it,” Dr. Strange murmurs appreciatively. “The pain lasts until Peter is fed.”

“Which he wasn’t likely to get if he went back to the fire station,” Hill says. “No wonder he made such a huge scene outside of the school. He wanted to give himself a head start.”

“Are you feeling well enough to eat, Master Peter?” Alfred asks politely. His voice is low and gentle, wary of triggering the migraine.

Peter, who has never been called a master anything, blinks up at him in confusion. “I think so, yeah. Uh. How long was I asleep?”

“Almost twelve hours,” Alfred says, arranging his pillows to support his back before pulling out the sides of the tray to turn it into a table. He sets the table in front of Peter and uncovers the tray. “Just a simple broth and bread for now, I’m afraid. We'll move on to more substantial food when you're feeling better.”

Peter eyes the soup warily. Food has been a laughable idea during every other migraine, but this is different. He picks up the spoon and takes a wary sip of the broth.

The pain disappears, only to be replaced with a ravenous hunger. Peter sets the spoon down, picks up the bowl, and outright drinks the broth. He drains it in seconds, sets the bowl down, and tears into the soft bread. It's the worst table manners he's ever shown, but he’s too hungry to care.

He's cleared the bowl and tray within a minute of Alfred setting it out for him. Alfred tilts his head and says, simply, "Hm. I see we're ready for another helping."

Peter rubs the back of his neck. "Er, sorry--"

"You have nothing to apologize for," Alfred says, taking the tray from him. "Nothing at all. Please wait a moment, I'll return shortly."

Peter doesn’t exactly have an option. The migraine hangover and the extreme hunger have robbed him of his desire to get up and move. The bed is too comfortable, the room is too warm, the sound of the rain is too soothing. Alfred leaves the room with the tray, gently shutting the door behind himself.

Peter leans back against the pillows, relaxing. There’s a bone deep itch tingling up his back and into his arms and legs. It may have just been broth and bread, but it was good broth and bread. Enough to help, at least. Peter settles into the bed fully, dozing. He snaps out of it when Alfred wheels in an entire cart full of food.

“I decided this would be much more efficient,” Alfred says. He sets out the tray again and covers it in small plates. Broth, soup, bread, water, tea. “Since Master Duke’s instincts were correct and it seems you only needed food to recover...”

“Yeah, I guess I did,” Peter says, staring at the food. He’s close to actually drooling.

“Then eat your fill, Master Peter. And don’t hesitate to ask for more. I understand things haven’t been going in your favor for quite some time,” Alfred says. The way he pauses at the sight of Peter makes Peter wonder exactly how bad he looks.

“You look like a starving orphan,” Drax says helpfully. “Small. Pale. Pathetic. Like a puppy that is sad.”

Great, thanks. Good to know.

Peter starts to eat. He clears the entire cart of food, eating the tray bare and sitting back while Alfred fills it again. By the time he drinks the last bit of soup and eats the last crumb of bread, he’s close to full and a low, tingly itch covers his body from head to toe. His healing factor is hard at work, apparently.

Alfred takes the tray from him one last time. “How do you feel?”

“Better. Great,” Peter says, fighting back a yawn. “Thank you.”

“You’re quite welcome,” Alfred replies. He tucks the blankets back around Peter. “Rest. When you’re feeling well enough, I’ve left a change of clothes in the bathroom.”

Peter is suddenly aware of how grimy he feels. “Yeah. Thanks.”

Alfred smiles, then leaves. Peter is asleep before the door shuts.

* * *

* * *

Peter wakes up, rolls out of bed, and shuffles straight for the bathroom tucked away into the corner of the room. He showers, revels in the warmth of the water, and then shuffles out. Clothes are neatly folded on a bench. Tim’s clothes, actually; jeans, socks, shirt, and--amusingly enough--a sport coat. He changes, then pulls his old shoes back on; he and Tim definitely don’t have the same shoe size and Peter’s work well enough for now.

He brushes his teeth, does his best to tame his hair, gives up, and steps back into the bedroom. He pauses to take in the room.

It's easily the size of his apartment back in Queens. There’s a bed, a desk, a small living room area complete with a small sofa, a plush chair, and a flat screen, and a door leading out to a balcony. Floor to ceiling windows line the wall, and beyond it, Peter can see the distant shape of Gotham City, muted by rain. It's strangely beautiful in the murky afternoon.

He takes stock of himself. He feels great; he's not hungry, he's clean, he's warm, and it feels as if he can think clearly for the first time in months. He needs to thank Tim and Duke for bringing him here for the night. He owes them.

It really is going to suck when he goes back to the fire station.

"For a genius, you're an idiot sometimes," Fury remarks.

Well, that’s just rude.

A knock on his door brings him back to himself, and he’s quick to cross the room and pull the door open.

Dick is standing on the other side. He takes in Peter’s appearance and perks up, smiling at him.

"Hey, Pete. How are you feeling?" he asks.

"Human, for once," Peter answers, running a hand through his hair. "Thanks for letting me stay the night. I think I needed it."

Dick pauses and tilts his head. "It isn't just for one night, Peter."

Peter frowns. "What?"

"We overheard everything last night. It sounds like Tony isn't coming back for you," Dick says after a moment.

Peter starts to protest, then stops. Tony isn't coming for him, but not for the reason Dick thinks. He frowns, staring past Dick.

"Yeah. I guess he isn't," he says after a long moment.

"You can stay here with us," Dick says. "Alfred’s already getting everything set up for you, and Duke and Tim are excited to have you here. Just stay here."

Peter stares at him. "Just like that?"

"Just like that," Dick says.

Peter mulls it over. It really isn't much of a decision; either freeze and starve in Crime Alley, or stay here where he's safe, warm, and close to his friends. Bonus: the balcony in his room will make it easy to slip out for patrol. So will the warm bed and food. He'd have to sneak around Tim, Duke, Dick, and Alfred, but that shouldn't be too hard, right? Especially in a place this big.

"Yeah. Yeah, okay," Peter says. "I, uh, think I'd like that."

Dick smiles in relief, reaching out to squeeze his shoulder. “Good. Welcome to the family, Peter.”

Peter is a little amused and curious about how quickly Dick has taken to him. He seems nice enough. Tim and Duke look up to him, and that’s good enough for Peter, but he’s curious about how familiar Dick is with him. They probably weren’t talking about him to their big brother, right?

“Uh, thanks,” Peter says, rubbing the back of his neck.

“Do you have anything you want to grab from your old place?” Dick says.

“Yeah, definitely. If you drop me off at a bus stop, I can go--”

Dick scoffs, holding up a set of car keys and motioning for Peter to follow him down the hall. “Yeah, right. Come on, I’ll drive you.”

“It’s in Crime Alley,” Peter says, following after him. He’s briefly overwhelmed by the size of the manor. They walk down a grand staircase, with a family portrait hanging above the landing. A family portrait that includes Bruce Fucking Wayne. “Are you, uh, sure you want to...”

“I can handle Spider Alley,” Dicks says dismissively, jogging down the steps. “We won’t be very long, and it’s day time anyway.”

Peter hesitates, takes one last look up at the family portrait on the wall--how had he missed Bruce taking in so many kids?--and follows Dick outside. He’s a lot less sure of his decision to stay at the manor now.

* * *

The drive into the city is quiet. The steady rain turns freezing, and then into a steady sleet. The roads turn slick and the ever present fog that envelops the city lowers to ground level. Dick turns on some music, attempts to make some small talk, and then ultimately gives up when Peter doesn’t respond much. He’s being rude, and he knows it, but he needs some time to think. It’s much easier now that he isn’t starving or exhausted. Imagine that.

How the fuck did he not notice that Tim and Duke are literally Bruce Wayne’s kids? How did he miss that? Even Steph was on the family portrait, and he had no clue she spent much time with Tim and Duke outside of school. At least, not that he’s noticed, but he also makes a habit of all but fleeing out of the school to go on patrol as soon as possible. He just never paid attention.

He has the sinking suspicion that Bruce knows he’s stolen from him, that he’s just indulged in Peter's theft. God, he hopes not, he knows he covered his tracks, but he’s not Ned. He might have missed something.

“So, where exactly am I taking you?” Dick asks after a moment. He frowns at the surrounding buildings. Half are in blatant disrepair and somehow look even more pathetic in the sleet and rain. “You never gave me an address.”

“Yeah, it’s in a weird spot. Parking is kind of at a premium,” Peter says. He points to a strip mall parking lot playing host to a flea market despite the fog, the chill, and the rain. It’s one of the safer parts of Crime Alley, and is coincidentally about as far as he wants to bring one of Bruce Wayne’s kids into it. “Just park here. I can walk the rest of the way.”

Dick glances at him from the corner of his eye, but dutifully turns off the main road and into the parking lot. He parks the car, turning it off. “I’ll walk with you--”

Peter’s out of the car the moment it stops, disappearing into the fog.

* * *

Sneaking off from Dick probably hadn’t been a good idea. He’ll find his way back to the man eventually; he did agree to live at the manor with everyone, after all. He just needs some time to himself to think. Somewhere away from the manor. Somewhere familiar. Which just happens to be the building he climbed up that first month in Gotham, where he met Nightwing. He hasn’t been here in awhile, and the climb up the fire escape had been mildly inconvenient with the icy rain, but he can withstand the cold much better today than usual.

Too bad his thoughts aren’t going anywhere helpful.

“I think you’ve sulked long enough,” Shuri says. “You should get your things.”

Yeah, probably. The sleet is starting to bother him. He sighs, standing up and stretching, before considering the ground below. He could just walk down the side of the building and avoid the slippery fire escape altogether. That’d be quicker, at least--

“Hey, I’d really appreciate it if you took a few steps back from that ledge,” a calm voice says behind him.

Peter startles in place and turns around to face the source of the voice. He ends up almost face to face with Dick Grayson, and aims a disbelieving look at him. That voice. It’s a different accent, but someone trained by Batman would know to train themselves to use something other than their natural speaking voice, wouldn’t they?

Dick smiles sadly, walking over to Peter. He offers him his hand, just as he did as Nightwing. Peter hesitates for a moment before taking it. He doesn’t need it, of course. He could sprint down the side of the building and be just fine. Dick takes hold of his hand and pulls him away from the ledge, shifting them so that he stands between Peter and the ice slick roof ledge.

“I wondered if you’d come back to this rooftop,” Dick says, keeping his hand on Peter’s shoulder. “You do like to come up here.”

“If I told you it’s not what it looks like, would you believe me?” Peter asks.

“Eventually, but probably not right now,” Dick admits, guiding Peter over to the fire escape.

“Yeah, figured as much,” Peter mutters. He climbs down the fire escape smoothly and drops to the asphalt with no problem; his old instincts are already in recovery after a few hearty meals from Alfred. “I really do come up here to think, by the way. Things are clearer.”

“I can’t fault you for that. I’m the same way with my night job,” Dick says. He brushes off his hands and looks up and down the street.

“Yeah, Tim never mentioned your night job,” Peter remarks. He wants to ask about that, wants to press him on the details, but holds off. Who knows who else is around?

Dick smiles at that, as if laughing at his own private joke. Then his expression softens and he glances around the neighborhood. It’s definitely not as nice as the run down strip mall where they parked. “I never could figure out why you’d choose this building. There’s nothing around here.”

“It’s next to where I live,” Peter says. He’s actually kind of going to miss this horrible little neighborhood.

Dick frowns at him. “There’s nothing around but half empty office buildings, warehouses, and an abandoned fire station. The nearest apartment is six blocks away, and that’s not safe territory to cross at night in Crime Alley.”

Peter shrugs, and motions for Dick to follow him over to the fire station. Dick follows him, but slows slightly when he sees Peter climb up the fire escape to the second floor window of the old fire station. The building, already a sad sight on a clear day, looks even worse with the onset of winter. Peter pauses at the window, crouching on the ledge, and looks down at Dick.

“You can wait there if you want. I won’t be long, promise,” Peter says. He ducks into the building and is pleasantly surprised to see that it’s mostly dry inside. Sure, a part of the roof is leaking, but it’s a slow trickle.

“Better hurry,” Bucky says. “Grayson’s behind you.”

Peter starts to pack up his things. There isn’t a lot, fortunately. His suit is tucked away in his backpack, he doesn’t have any food to take, and he can just leave the electronics for now. A few are ruined by the leak, but they were already broken anyway.

He hears Dick step in through the window and stop.

Peter doesn’t look up, focused on packing. “Hey, I wanted to talk to you about last night, by the way.”

“Yeah?” Dick says, subdued.

“Yeah. About Tony. What you saw wasn’t him, for the record,” Peter says, gathering his things. He picks up the Stark radio he made months ago and turns it off. He doesn’t need the alarm function anymore. “He’s not actually like that. He doesn’t drink anymore, he isn’t some selfish monster. He’s--he’s a hero. Genuinely.”

It sounds hollow and unconvincing even to his own ears. He sighs, packing away the rest of his things and turns to face Dick. He freezes when he sees the expression on Dick’s face. Horrified is too mild a word. Heartbroken is close, but it doesn’t encompass the furious set to his jaw.

Peter stands there awkwardly for a moment, suddenly realizing how this must look. He fidgets with the Stark radio in his hands, then clears his throat. “I, uh. I’ve got everything I need.”

Dick takes one last look around the fire station, eyes roaming across Peter’s makeshift desk, ramshackle lights, and 'bedroom' made of a tarp and ragged blankets, and takes in a deep breath, obviously fighting back a surge of fury.

"Good. Let's go home."

The parent-teacher conference is going well enough, Peter supposes, despite the simmering tension and annoyance he has towards Loki. He follows Tim into the gym and frowns at how empty it is. In fact, there are only two other people in the gym: Duke and Felicia, who are sitting at the same table and deeply engrossed in a game of paper football. Duke’s shot goes wide and Felicia raises her hands in apparent victory.

“Where is everyone?” Peter asks, frowning at the empty room. The stillness annoys him somehow.

Tim shrugs, waving at Duke before walking towards him with Peter. “We’re the last appointments for the night, so we get the gym all to ourselves.”

“Huh,” Peter says. Felicia brightens when she sees him and she scoots over on the bench so he can sit beside her. He drops down on to the bench and smiles at Duke and then her. He pitches his voice low enough that only she can hear. “I totally saw you cheat just then. With your luck powers.”

“I didn’t cheat,” Felicia whispers back. She smirks. “It only counts as cheating if you’re caught.”

“That’s completely untrue,” he retorts, fighting back a small grin when she winks at him.

“Hey, lovebirds,” Tim says. “What’re you two whispering about?”

“Peter’s inability to see things from my point of view,” Felicia replies. She nudges Peter with her shoulder when he rolls his eyes. “Who’d you bring along anyway?”

“Tony,” Tim says.

Felicia freezes. “What.”

“It’s a long story,” Peter says, shooting Tim a warning look. He gets only a curious quirk of the eyebrow in response. “But yeah, someone is here for me.”

“Oh, really?” Felicia asks, turning to face Peter completely.

“Yes, really,” Peter says, shifting uncomfortably. His frustration is starting to build again, the anger rising up unbidden. Felicia’s about to launch into another round of questions and Peter heads her off at the pass, standing up. “Listen, I’m starving, I’m going to go grab a snack.”

“Get me a candy bar while you’re at it,” Felicia says. Her eyes narrow just a bit, as well. She sees right through him, of course.

“Right, one terrible chocolate bar coming right up,” Peter says, reaching into his pocket to grab his wallet as he heads for the nearest . His frustration eases somewhat when he’s put some distance between himself and his friends, and he breathes a quiet sigh of relief when he reaches the hallway.

“You’re losing it, man,” Quill points out, quite unnecessarily.

Yeah, he might’ve noticed. What is he even doing here? He should have blown off the conference entirely. Just ignored it. Instead, he’s here, with Loki, trying to pretend to be normal. And now he has to dream up some explanation to Felicia, who is definitely going to ask him why Iron Man has time to show up for a stupid parent/teacher conference but doesn’t have time to invent a way back home.

God, she’s going to be so pissed at him when he explains it to her. Because he will; he doesn’t want to lie to the only other person from home he’s found. Besides, she’d see right through it. She’s smart. Peter thumps his head against the vending machine, putting in a crumpled five dollar bill to grab Felicia’s candy for her. The machine eats it, of course, and Peter’s annoyance flares into true anger for the first time that night. He grabs the machine, gripping it tightly--

“Put it down,” T’Challa says evenly.

Peter didn’t even realize he was holding it in the air. He pauses, then gently sets it back down and backs away from the machine with a shaky sigh. Okay, so maybe Loki was right. Maybe his anger issues are becoming worse. He runs a shaky hand through his hair and sighs, staring at the vending machine glumly.

That was his last five dollars, dammit.

Peter takes in a deep breath before heading back to the gym. He pushes open the door and freezes.

Sometime between Peter leaving the gym and returning, the Joker showed up. Along with his little clown gang. Tim and Duke are tied up, both watching the Joker. The Joker is standing near the door, near Peter, holding a revolver aimed squarely at Felicia’s head.

Peter pauses only for a moment before stalking inside. “Hey!”

“Oh, goody, another hostage!” Joker cries out in that infuriating singsong tone of his. “Tie yourself up with the others or I’ll blow her brains out.”

Peter glances at Felicia for only a moment, his stride never faltering. Joker scowls, and pulls the trigger. The gun clicks, the bullet jamming and preventing it from firing; likely a result of Felicia’s luck powers. That little click, with the knowledge that Duke, Felicia, and Tim are in mortal danger sends his fury to a new level. He closes in on the Joker.

The Joker whirls to face Peter, clearing the jam, and aims the gun at his heart. He starts to pull the trigger--

Peter clamps his hand down over the Joker’s and squeezes. He crushes the gun in Joker’s hand, the metal crunching between his fingers as the gunpowder slips to the ground. The Joker’s hand is similarly destroyed, and his grin turns pained and vaguely panicked when the delicate bones of his hand are crushed. The grin turns disbelieving when Peter pivots on one foot and flings the Joker into the wall across the room. The man hits the wall with the same heavy thump sound a bag of wet cement makes when dropped. There are a few crackling noises when he starts to move and Peter idly wonders how many of the man’s bones he just broke. Usually this thought is followed by anxiety or sickening guilt. He feels none right now.

In fact, he can hear the Joker’s heartbeat from here, can hear him breathe in a pain chuckle, and he feels quite the opposite. He’s almost completely lost to his rage. It burns cold, filling him with an icy determination as he stalks towards Joker. The Joker’s minions, upon seeing this, sprint out of the nearest doors, leaving their weapons behind. Good for them. He might chase them down once he’s done with Joker---

Felicia steps in front of him, hands held out. “Peter, enough. He’s down.”

“Move,” Peter orders. His voice is flat and furious.

“No,” Felicia says, planting herself firmly in his path. When he tries to move around her, she matches him, one to one, reaching out to grab his arms. “Stop.”

He stops, annoyed, but unwilling to hurt Felicia. He would never hurt his friends, not even when he’s this furious. But the anger is still there, and he glares at her, clenching his fists.

“Why are you defending him?” he snaps. “Do you know what he’s done? What he was going to do to you?”

“I do! But this isn’t you,” Felicia says. He can see the wariness in her eyes, but she doesn’t show any other sign of fear. “Spiderman doesn’t kill. Everyone back home knew that.”

Tim and Duke, already watching them in shock, go very still.

“This isn’t home,” Peter says after a long moment.

“But you’re still Spiderman,” Felicia insists. “Don’t do this. You know you’ll regret it for the rest of your life if you do.”

Peter trembles with rage, looking from Felicia to Joker and back again. Finally he lets out a frustrated snarl of fury and whirls away from Felicia and Joker both, slamming a fist on the nearest table. It snaps in half and collapses to the gym floor. Peter closes his eyes and takes in a deep breath.

“Control it,” Bucky says. “You can’t let it get away from you.”

“Deep breaths, Peter,” Shuri adds. “Give yourself a moment to come back from the anger.”

Irritation and frustration go to war in his mind, but the longer he focuses on his shoes, the more it drains away. It leaves him, bit by bit, leaving exhaustion in its place. Behind him, he hears Felicia untie Tim and Duke.

“Help him,” Felicia whispers. “I’m going to go check on our parents.”

“We’ve got him,” Duke says.

He hears Felicia slip out of the door, focusing on his breathing. And he hears two others approach him, slowly and cautiously, and suddenly feels very tired. He let his strength get away from him and now his friends are probably terrified of him.

Great.

“Easy, man,” Duke says, reaching out to grab his shoulder. “Give it a minute. The anger will go away.”

Tim leans around in front of him, looking him in the eye, then scanning his face. “Green eyes. White streak of hair. Ghosts. Preternatural strength. And mood swings. I can’t believe we didn’t put it together before.”

“Put what together?” Peter asks, shaking out his fist. He hasn’t used his super strength like this in a long time, and he’s more than a little disturbed by it.

“You were the person who came out of the Lazarus Machine,” Tim says, as if that should make any kind of sense to Peter.

“I don’t know what that is,” Peter says, grounding himself through Duke’s hold on his shoulder. He sighs and sits down at the nearest table. The one that isn’t a pile of wood and debris, at least. Duke stays close, still with that comforting hand on his shoulder.

“Ugly gray thing with a glass tube inside of it. And green liquid,” Tim says. “It brings people back from the dead and has a habit of making them completely insane when they come back. We call it Pit Madness.”

“Oh,” Peter says dimly. “Yeah. That thing. I remember now.”

“What do you remember from it?” Duke asks warily.

“Mostly that it hurt. And I was drowning in it, but I couldn’t fully drown,” Peter says, gaze unfocusing. “I think they didn’t get it right the first few times.”

Tim and Duke have matching horrified expressions.

“The first few times?” Tim asks.

“I...I don’t want to remember it,” Peter mutters, rubbing the back of his neck. He suddenly feels too hot and too cold, and his hands start to shake of their own volition. “It hurt. A lot. And I don’t--”

“You don’t have to,” Duke cuts in gently. “We’ll worry about that later.”

“Yeah. Yeah, that sounds good.”

The door to the gym slams open. Dick Grayson charges into the room, a fire axe in hand. He stops when he sees the destruction in the gym, and the crumpled and broken form of Joker on the other side of the room. He takes in the scene, lowers the axe to the ground and walks over to Tim, Duke, and Peter.

“What happened?” Dick asks.

“The Joker tried to kill us and I threw him into a wall,” Peter says. “Felicia stopped me from killing him.”

Dick takes that in with surprising calm. “Huh. Okay.”

“Peter’s Spiderman, by the way,” Tim says helpfully.

“Okay,” Dick repeats, a bit less calmly now.

“And he came out of the Lazarus Machine we found awhile back,” Duke adds.

“Great,” Dick says. “Stop saying things now.”

“Where’s Felicia?” Peter asks. He’s suddenly very tired.

“With Selina,” Dick says. “She left with her the moment they found each other. She said the Joker was our problem and she didn’t want Felicia getting mixed up with it.”

“Makes sense,” Peter says.

“Hang on, time out,” Duke says. “Felicia is Selina’s daughter?”

“Apparently,” Dick says. “Honestly, Joker’s lucky she wasn’t hurt. I’ve never seen Selina so protective. Kinda scary.”

“Felicia’s been through a lot. She needs that,” Peter says.

“Says the guy who drowned in a Lazarus Machine more times than he can count,” Tim says dryly.

“Okay, it was, like, at most four times, guys. Calm down.”

“That’s not any better!” Duke says in exasperated horror.

Dick has his head in his hands now. “Can the three of you please use the fire exit in the back corner so we can all go home?”

“Wait,” Peter says, standing up. “Where’s Tony?”

“Gone,” Dick says, his tone carefully neutral. “He ran the moment the men with guns came into the cafeteria.”

“Of course he did,” Peter says bitterly. “Guess I’m walking home--”

“Duke, help him for us,” Sam says quietly. “He’s been getting worse ever since he came out of that machine.”

Duke freezes for a moment, then walks up and slings an arm across Peter’s shoulders. “Nope, you’re coming home with us.”

“What?” Peter asks, frowning up at the taller boy.

“You think I’m gonna pass up a chance to talk with Spiderman? Come on,” Duke scoffs. “Sorry, man, you’re stuck with us tonight.”

“And maybe a bit longer than that,” Tim adds quietly. “Pit Madness is nothing to scoff at, Peter. We can help you with that.”

“How?” Peter asks, turning to aim a questioning look at Tim. Duke has a firm arm across his shoulders in a hug that isn’t quite protective, but isn’t far off from it.

“The long and short version is therapy,” Dick says, guiding the three of them over to his car. “Coming back from the dead is rough. It changes people.”

Peter isn’t sure he wants to start that particular healing process yet. But he’s positive he can’t keep dealing with these bursts of rage on his own. Not as he has been. He frowns, going quiet.

“For now,” Dick continues. “You can stay with us. Alfred’s already got a room for you.”

* * *

Peter settles into life at Wayne manor uneasily. He steadfastly refuses to talk to the others about Tony, or where he’s been staying, and he can only guess at what they think of where he came from. It isn’t good. He knows that much. Dick accidentally walked in on him changing shirts once and saw the bruises covering Peter’s chest and back. The man had tensed, clenched his jaw, gently apologized for intruding, and then left.

Peter has no idea how to explain the bruises came from his patrols as Spiderman, so he doesn’t.

* * *

Felicia visits him the next day, leaping up onto the balcony outside his bedroom and gently tapping on the door to get his attention. Peter dutifully opens it for her and steps outside. The wind is sharp and cold, and it cuts through his sweatpants and t-shirt immediately. He ignores it; he’s still conditioned against it from living in that horrible fire station for months on end.

Felicia isn’t in her costume this time. She came as herself. She’s balanced on the railing, watching him curiously.

“Hi,” he says.

“Hey, you,” Felicia says. “Looks like you found your Selina.”

“Yeah, I guess so,” Peter says, rubbing the back of his neck. “It almost seems too easy.”

“So? Maybe you should take the easy path every now and then,” Felicia says. She tilts her head. “Do they know?”

“No, not yet,” Peter admits. “They’re waiting for Bruce to come back to have some big family meeting.”

Felicia hums, idly kicking her feet. “What will you tell them?”

Peter is quiet for a moment. Finally, he says, “Everything. Will you help me?”

Felicia smiles, ducking in close to kiss his cheek. “All you had to do was ask, spider.”

When Peter wakes up, it happens all at once. One moment, he’s in a deep, restful sleep and the next he’s wide awake and on his feet. His stomach clenches painfully; a half day at school has robbed him of the largest meal of his deal, and the sandwich Lou gave him this morning is long gone apparently. He runs a hand through his hair, attempts to smooth out the wrinkles in his uniform, and checks the time. And then groans.

The conference starts in an hour and he’s still no closer to figuring out a solution than he was before his sudden nap. He sighs, grabs his notebook and a pen, and starts to doodle. Doodling helps him think, calms him down. He lets the pen move on its own, frustrated and hungry.

If he had help maybe---

There’s a flash of gold. And suddenly, Sam Wilson is standing in the middle of the room, wearing jeans, a plain shirt, a brown leather jacket, and simple tennis shoes. His wings are noticeably absent. Peter stops midstep, staring at Sam blankly. Sam seems as shocked as Peter.

“Huh. Guess that snake wasn’t lying after all.” He rolls his shoulders, stomps his feet, and lets out a relieved sigh when his body obeys each command as it should. He pats his pocket and pulls out a wallet, peering inside before nodding and pocketing it again. “Okay, everything’s where it should be. Probably. Come on, kid, let’s get a move on. Loki can’t keep this up forever.”

“What,” Peter asks dumbly, after a significant pause.

“Your conference. I’m standing in for Tony tonight,” Sam says. He pauses, frowns. “We’re going to stop and get you some food on the way. You look like hell.”

“I feel like it, too,” Peter mutters. He frowns, fidgeting some, but follows Sam towards the window and the fire escape. “Loki used a spell to bring you here?”

“Yeah, he did. Even brought back my stuff,” Sam says, holding up his wallet again before pocketing it. He hops down to the street lightly.

“Will your cards work?” Peter asks him, dropping down beside him.

“No, but the cash will,” Sam says. He nods towards the subway station. “I’ve got fifty bucks and know at least three places we can hit up on the way to your school.”

“Won’t that make us late?” Peter asks, frowning up at him.

Sam shrugs. “Only a little. And who cares? If things play out right, we won’t need to worry about you starving after tonight.”

Peter feels a rush of relief. Things will be easier if Sam’s here. He’s Captain America’s best friend, right? He knows how to handle situations like this. Sure, they’re not super close, but he trusts the man based on that alone.

“That’d be nice,” Peter says.

Sam smiles at him briefly.

“I’ve got you, Pete. Don’t worry,” he says.

* * *

Sam takes him to Batburger and buys half the menu. He doesn’t eat anything himself; he simply kicks back in his seat and looks around the restaurant while Peter demolishes the burgers, fries, and onion rings spread across the table in front of him. He has a wistful look on his face.

“What’s up?” Peter asks around a mouthful of cheeseburger.

“Man, eat with your mouth closed,” Sam replies, tossing a straw wrapper at him. “And nothing. It’s just nice to see people clearly again.”

“You didn’t see things before?” Peter asks.

“We did, but nothing’s clear. It’s like walking through frosted glass most of the time. We see people close to you, but it’s hard to hear them sometimes. Everything’s muffled,” Sam says. “Duke and Nightwing are the only ones we can see clearly from any distance. Duke more than Nightwing. Usually we just see and hear you. Your thoughts and feelings.”

“Huh,” Peter says. “I wonder why?”

“We’ve got a few working theories,” Sam says. He checks his watch. “Finish up, the parent teacher conference starts in thirty minutes.”

“We’re fifteen minutes away from the school,” Peter says. “We’ll get there on time.”

“There’s no such thing as on time. You’re either early or late,” Sam replies.

Peter rolls his eyes, but dutifully cleans up his mess and heads for the door with Sam. He feels great after that meal, and his mood, already high now that he has an Avenger with him, climbs higher when the food hits him. He’s even a little energetic, lightly bouncing on his feet, ready to take on the world.

Sam shakes his head, amused, and pushes the door open for Peter. “Man, you’re just like my nephews.”

* * *

Sam whistles lowly as they walk up the sidewalk leading to Gotham Prep. The school looks foreboding in the night, lit up against the night with dark storm clouds roiling above it threateningly. The smell of rain lingers heavy in the air, and thunder rolls in the distance. Other parents and students are walking to and from the entrance, most of them heading inside, but there’s a small group gathered at the entrance: Tim, Duke, Selina, Felicia, a brown skinned man wearing business casual clothes, and Bruce Wayne.

As in, the Bruce Wayne Peter’s stolen from.

The same Bruce Wayne who is smiling fondly at Selina while Tim and Duke look vaguely shellshocked beside him.

Peter stutters to a stop on the sidewalk. Tim and Duke spot him immediately, of course, and both nod or wave and then focus on Sam. Tim frowns and tilts his head curiously. Duke stares in open mouthed shock. Felicia’s expression isn’t much different from Duke’s. Neither reaction goes unnoticed by the rest of their group; Bruce, Selina, Felicia, and the brown skinned man all turn to look at Peter and Sam.

“Oh, shit,” Peter mutters. “Why is Bruce Wayne here?”

“Probably the same reason I’m here,” Sam says, mild amusement in his tone. “What’s wrong?”

“I, uh, don’t think this is a good idea,” Peter says. “We should go back--”

“It’s a little late to get cold feet now, Pete,” Sam says mildly, smiling and waving at the small group.

Bruce returns the wave.

“We could sprint away into the night, maybe?”

“Nope,” Sam says, walking towards the school.

Peter sighs, but follows him. Naturally, that’s when the rain outside starts to fall. Peter doesn’t have his umbrella with him, or his blazer, or the jacket he normally wears when leaving the firestation. He’s just wearing a plain button down shirt with his uniform slacks. He sighs when the rain pelts him full force.

“Dammit,” he mutters.

Sam stops, shrugs off his jacket, and drops it on Peter’s head. “Use that.”

Peter blinks, but pulls it on. It’s far too big for him--Sam is just as broad shouldered and strong as Cap, after all--but it’s warm. He has to roll up the sleeves just so his hands aren’t lost inside them. It’s the most comfortable thing he’s worn since he came to Gotham.

“Thanks,” he says.

Sam nods, and they close distance with the others quickly. Bruce smiles, easy and friendly, and offers his hand to Sam.

“Hi, Bruce Wayne. These are my sons, Dick, Duke, and Tim,” he says, nodding to each in turn.

“Sam Wilson, filling in for Tony tonight,” Sam says, shaking his hand. He smiles at Duke and Tim. “Hey, guys. Peter’s told me a lot about you two.”

“I’m sure he has,” Duke says slowly. There’s an odd tone to his voice that the Waynes pick up on immediately.

Sam turns his attention to Selina and Felicia, offering his hand to them both. “Ma’am, Felicia. Good to meet you both.”

“You too,” Selina says pleasantly.

“You’re Sam Wilson,” Felicia says numbly. “How are you here?”

“Long story. Ask Pete, he can fill you in,” Sam says. “Unfortunately, I don’t think we have a lot of time.”

“No, we don’t,” Bruce says, pulling the door open and motioning for everyone to head inside. “Let’s get inside before the storm gets worse. Here, I’ll show you where to go.”

“Thanks, I appreciate it,” Sam says, holding the door open for Peter, Felicia, and Selina before following them into the school.

* * *

Duke hangs back with Tim, watching the rain, trying to get his thoughts in order. The rain is pulling no punches now, and the thunder is a constant growl in the sky above. Tim watches his brother for a moment.

“Sam Wilson,” Tim says idly. “Huh.”

“One of Peter’s ghosts,” Duke says.

“I know,” Tim says, drinking his coffee.

“You do?” Duke asks, facing him. “How? I’ve never described him to you.”

“The rain,” Tim points out. “He was standing in the middle of all that rain and was perfectly dry.”

* * *

Bruce, Sam, and Selina walk three abreast, talking amongst each other in pleasant tones. The typical “hi-how-are-you-what-do-you-do” kind of conversation people seem to fall into once they’ve hit full adulthood. Peter tunes it out; he trusts Sam. He doesn’t need to keep up with everything the man is saying.

He walks beside Felicia, who is still caught up in some kind of disbelieving shock. Peter spares her a few worried glances as they head down the hall. The brown skinned man, Dick, offers his hand to Peter.

“Hey, Peter,” he says. “It’s good to meet you.”

His tone is earnest and friendly, and the way he says Peter’s name seems oddly familiar. Peter returns his smile and shakes his hand politely. “You too.”

“The students are supposed to stay in the gym during the conferences,” Dick says. He nods towards the double doors at the end of the hallway. “There should be snacks there.”

“Thanks,” Peter says. He nudges Felicia, who blinks at him, before stiffly turning and walking down the hall. Peter fights back a sigh.

“Is she okay?” Dick asks, frowning.

“Exams next week. You know.” Peter shrugs. It’s not a convincing lie, and also probably not true. He has no idea when exams start up.

Dick is polite enough to not comment on it. “Huh. Okay.”

“It was nice meeting you,” Peter says politely before heading down the hall himself.

He’s barely through the gym doors when Felicia appears beside him, staring at him hard.

“How is Sam Wilson here?” she hisses.

Peter takes in a deep breath and lets it out slowly, fidgeting with Sam’s jacket.

“Okay,” he says. “This is going to be a weird one.”

* * *

The conferences are going well. Sam is polite, attentive, and perfectly charming towards Peter’s teachers. He’s also being watched like a hawk by Bruce Wayne and Dick Grayson. Selina is much more subtle about it, but just as focused. That suits him fine. He knows who they are; all of the Dusted see other souls as they truly are, and he’d recognize Nightwing and Batman anywhere. He finishes the last meeting of the evening and checks his watch. And then pauses and looks at his hand.

A single flake of ash falls from his hand and drifts to the floor. Sam watches it fall, considers what it means, and what Loki and Strange told him in the Soul Stone shortly before Peter woke up.

He doesn’t have much time left. He pauses for a moment, gathers his thoughts, and walks towards Bruce and Dick. Both men are in quiet conversation with each other and fall silent when he gets close. They wear matching expressions, equal parts curious and wary, as if they aren’t sure what to make of him.

He leans against the wall beside them and says, in a voice just loud enough for them to hear, “Batman, Nightwing, I need your help. It’s about Peter.”

If he had their curiosity before, he has their alarmed attention now. Bruce and Dick share a brief expression with one another before Bruce nods to Sam.

“What can we do for you, Sam?” Bruce asks.

* * *

Ten minutes later, the whole group is walking outside and into the parking lot. The rain has softened into a light mist that drifts past the streetlights, and the thunder has fallen silent. The air is chill and damp, but it doesn’t affect Peter’s mood much. The parking lot is empty except for a few cars and Peter’s little group. He and Sam are walking ahead of the pack, but he slows when Sam reaches out to grab his shoulder and tug him off to the side for a few steps.

“Hey, listen, I don’t have much time left,” Sam says, and there’s genuine regret in his tone. “Loki and Strange can’t keep this up forever.”

Peter freezes. “What? You’re not--”

“No, I’m not back. Not fully. And you probably won’t be able to hear me for a long time after this,” Sam says. He shrugs at Peter’s confused frown. “This was a one time deal. I’m kind of burning up my soul to pull this off.”

“You’re--what?” Peter asks, horrified. “Why would you--”

“To get you help. I promised I’d take care of you, and I meant,” Sam says. “When we finish talking, you’re going to go talk to Bruce and Dick and tell them what’s going on with you. They’re going to help you.”

“Sam, no, I can’t,” Peter says. “I can’t get them wrapped up in this. If they get hurt because of me--”

He trails off. Sam watches him evenly; Peter can tell he’s getting nowhere with the man. He clenches his jaw. "It's my fault we lost. Everyone else--if I'd been stronger or faster, he never would've had the chance--”

“Bullshit,” Sam says.

“--and then I got off light,” Peter says, talking over Sam. “I came back--”

"Bullshit," Sam says, cutting him off. "He made sure you suffered worse than anyone else. He killed you as slowly and painfully as he could."

"How do you know?" Peter asks, frowning at him.

"We watched it happen. We watched him pull you apart in front of Tony! We were there,” Sam says.

Peter freezes. They watched him die? God, he’d been babbling like a terrified child, clinging to Tony and begging him for help. He stares at Sam, shocked.

“You had it worse than any one of us and you know it!" Sam snaps, crowding him. "Ever since you woke up in that weird ass machine, you've been avoiding help and putting yourself in danger because you think you don’t deserve it.”

“I can handle it,” Peter says. The unsaid half of the sentence passes between them: Because I don’t deserve it.

“The hell you can!” Sam says. “If you keep it up, you'll die again. For real this time. I'm not gonna let that happen."

“Sam--” Peter starts. And then he stops. To his horror, Sam starts to flake away and crumble into ash, just like the Guardians did on Titan. Just like he did. Peter’s panic is both instantaneous and overwhelming.

"No, no, no--how do I stop it?" he asks, reaching out to grab Sam. He grabs nothing but ash and dust. It clings to his hands and sticks to his fingers. He makes a quiet, panicked keening noise. "Not again--"

"You can't stop it,” Sam says gently. He’s in pain, but he’s doing his best to not show it. “Just get some help, man. Take care of yourself."

And then he's gone. Peter trembles, clutching the ashes in his hands, staring at the ground where the Avenger had stood only seconds before. A hand falls on his shoulder. He looks up and, through his tears, finds himself locking eyes with Bruce Wayne. The look he gives Peter is sympathetic, maybe even heartbroken.

"Come on," he says, his tone gentle. "Sam wanted us to talk. All of us."

“What did he tell you?” Peter asks him numbly.

“Everything. And I just overheard the details he didn’t share,” Bruce says.

The Compound is exactly how he left it. Tony is both glad and annoyed by that realization. He’s also annoyed by how quiet and subdued the reporters are in the next room. He’s been to thousands of press conferences and press releases, and he can count on one hand how many were this quiet. Reporters are chatty by default, always jockeying for inside scoops even among their own, especially when it comes to Stark Industries. They’re eerily silent now, just like the cities, just like the social media feeds, just like everything is. Six months ago, the world ended, and the shocked silence lingers, along with the dust.

The same dust that’s blotting out the sun and causing a nuclear winter, in fact. The reason why he’s here.

The lessons seemed bone deep and lifelong at the time, but ever since Titan, he’s struggled to maintain his press ready persona.

A lot of things have gotten harder since Titan, really.

“Wouldn’t dream of missing it,” Tony says, giving in to his fidgeting and adjusting his cufflinks. His suit coat is open, and the first three buttons are undone to make room for the arc reactor beneath his shirt. Tony nods. Money doesn’t really account for much in the post apocalypse, but logistics does. And logistics running on clean power that can self-sustain for years at a time is a necessity. Tony is yanked right out of the reality he’s always known.

He’s moving faster than he ever has in his life, dragged through a landscape of shadowy nothing. Loki has an iron grip on his arm with one hand while the other clings to a thin red thread that shouldn’t be capable of pulling anyone along at speed, let alone two full adults. Loki glances back at him.

“We have a few minutes before we arrive. I’ll need to fill you in,” he says.

“Fill me in? On what?” Tony asks. He slowly reaches for the arc reactor on his chest.

Loki notices, of course. How can he not? They’re in a void. “Peter Parker is alive, and he needs your help. I assume that has your attention?”

It does.

Loki tells him everything. Tony listens.

By the time they reach their destination, Tony has already started to make plans.

When Peter wakes up, it happens all at once. One moment, he’s in a deep, restful sleep and the next he’s wide awake and on his feet. His stomach clenches painfully; a half day at school has robbed him of the largest meal of his deal, and the sandwich Lou gave him this morning is long gone apparently. He runs a hand through his hair, attempts to smooth out the wrinkles in his uniform, and checks the time. And then groans.

The conference starts in an hour and he’s still no closer to figuring out a solution than he was before his sudden nap. He sighs, grabs his notebook and a pen, and starts to doodle. Doodling helps him think, calms him down. He lets the pen move on its own, frustrated and hungry.

If he had help maybe---

There’s a flash of gold. And suddenly, Tony Stark is standing in the middle of the room, wearing the same suit he wore the day he offered to make Peter an Avenger at the Compound. He looks around in blatant confusion. Peter stops midstep, staring at Tony blankly. Tony seems as shocked as Peter.

“Jesus, Peter? Is that you?” Tony asks, his voice raw. “Your eyes--”

“I--yeah, it’s me,” Peter says. “How are you here?”

“Loki just popped up and grabbed me. He said you needed my help.” Tony says, taking in his surroundings. He frowns, walking towards Peter and looking him over. The longer he looks, the more alarmed he seems to become. “He wasn’t kidding. Have you been living like this?”

“I mean, it’s better than the streets,” Peter mumbles, rubbing the back of his neck. “And it’s worked--”

The rest of his sentence is cut off. Tony grips his shoulders, steadies him for a moment, and then pulls him into a fierce, protective hug. Peter pauses for a moment, thrown, and then melts into the embrace, mumbling against Tony’s shoulder.

“Oh. This is nice.”

He sags into the hug and Tony has to shift his feet to keep from losing balance. They stay like that for a moment before Tony leans back, taking stock of Peter. The “God, kid. You look like shit.”

“If you came all the way here just to tell me that, I’m going to say you’re way more petty than I thought,” Peter says through a watery grin. “Are you here to stay?”

“No, I’m not,” Tony says. “Loki and Dr. Strange are keeping me here. They won’t be able to keep it up for more than eight hours.”

That’s no time at all. Peter’s shoulders sag.

“But I have ideas on how to get back,” Tony says. He pulls the arc reactor off of his undershirt and puts it into Peter’s hand. “You hold onto this. And here, this too.”

He pulls out his cell phone. It isn’t registered for any networks here--Stark Communications definitely isn’t a thing in this universe--but Peter knows it can carry a charge for months at a time and the wifi should work just as well. It also has a copy of FRIDAY on it; nowhere near as sophisticated as her Compound self, but a genuine AI. Tony shoves his phone into Peter’s hand beside the arc reactor. Finally, he pulls out his wallet and pulls out a ludicrous amount of bills.

“Tony--” Peter starts, alarmed.

“Trust me, kid, it isn’t worth much back home. Not anymore. Take it,” Tony says. He pauses, glances around the fire station for a long moment, and lets out a slow breath. “Right. Okay. Tech, money, now to get you somewhere safe. With an actual roof over your head.”

“I mean, the roof here only leaks sometimes,” Peter says.

Tony gives him a flat look. “I’m ignoring that. You have friends here? Loki said something about a girl? Felicity or something.”

“Felicia. And I’m not sure her guardian will let me sleep there,” Peter says, rubbing the back of his neck. “Since I’m dating her adopted kid?”

“Yeah, that’s probably not going to happen. Your friends, then? Duke?” Tony asks.

Peter hesitates. “I mean, yeah, they probably will let me stay, but I don’t know how long--”

“Long enough,” Tony says, decision clearly already made. He looks around, and heads for the window Peter’s been using as his front door for the fire station. “Come on. Let’s go talk to them at that conference. I’ll even meet your teachers.”

Peter stands in the middle of the fire station, clutching a phone, an arc reactor, and enough money to keep himself fed for six months. He boggles at his luck, boggles more at the fact that this is happening at all, and then quickly pockets the money and phone. After a few moments of hesitation, he unbuttons his uniform shirt and gently places the arc reactor on his own undershirt, quickly doing up the buttons again. The reactor is solid and warm against his chest, even through his shirt, and its gentle glow is hidden by the fabric of his uniform shirt. It’s a comforting weight; proof that this is happening for real.

Tony calls out from the fire escape. “Clock’s ticking, kid, let’s go!”

* * *

Tony grabs burgers for them on the way. They eat on the move. Tony seems to be enjoying the burger as much as Peter, if not more. At Peter’s questioning look, he sighs.

“Meat’s kind of a luxury these days back home. Don’t worry about it, kid,” he says, balling up the wrapper and tossing it into the nearest bin. Peter mimics the move, but with more flourish and nails it. Tony smirks. “Show off.”

“Gotta keep you humble, old man,” Peter says, grinning back at him.

Tony scoffs, nudging Peter with his elbow. He stops suddenly and turns to Peter, his expression serious. “Listen, no matter what happens, I will find you. All right? I will come back for you.”

Peter blinks up at him, and smiles. “Yeah. I know you will.”

Tony nods, clapping Peter’s shoulder before walking with him towards the school. He keeps his hand there as they walk towards the school. Peter grins at Duke and Tim with a free and easy smile that they’ve never seen from him before, lifting a hand up to wave at them as they approach.

Felicia is staring at Tony and Peter with nothing short of absolute shock on her face.

Tony frowns at him in confusion, then looks at his hand. He clenches his fist. Ashes fall like snow from his hand. It’s significantly less handlike now and Tony curses, covering it with his free hand. He can feel the pain of it now, and it’s sharp enough to make him inhale.

“Goddammit,” Tony hisses. The pain is crawling up his arm now. He has seconds. “He promised he’d give me more time--”

“How do we stop it?” Dick asks, clearly out of his depth but doing his best to keep calm. Tony’s opinion of the man raises a few more notches.

“You don’t,” Tony says. “Get me out of here before I cause a scene. I can’t do this in front of the kid’s teachers--”

Dick grabs his good arm and leads him through a nearby fire exit propped open to let in fresh air. Tony stumbles into the frigid, wet air outside and braces himself against the slick wall of the school. The pain is worse now; a burning sensation that cuts a searing line up his arm. Ash falls out of his sleeve like a waterfall, and then that starts to flake away, too.

“You don’t have knees anymore,” Dick says numbly. “And that isn’t necessary.”

And then he collapses into a pile of ashes. A gust of frigid air sweeps away the ashes.

Dick Grayson is alone.
