“Also, I’m sorry about what I’m about to do. You’ll thank me later,” Nightwing says.

He pulls something out of his utility belt, a small spray bottle. And then he sprays it directly into Peter’s nose and mouth through the mask. The mask is fabric, thin and porous, because the Black Order didn’t trust him with metal armor. Whatever the chemical is, it passes right through the fabric easily.

He becomes woozy in an instant, staggering back and away from Nightwing with a choking cough. The ground tilts beneath him, and his mind becomes fuzzy. He stumbles and falls onto his side, blearily staring at Nightwing. Nightwing stands and walks over to him, kneeling down beside him and gripping his shoulder in a comforting manner.

“Easy. It’s just a sedative,” Nightwing says. “We’re going to help you, okay? I promise we won’t hurt you.”

Peter struggles against the chemical agent, refusing to sleep. Panic starts to claim him--

“You can trust him,” Sam Wilson says.

“We’ll protect you if they try to hurt you,” Bucky adds.

Peter can sense the ghosts a bit more now. He relaxes and lets sleep take him.

Life at Wayne Manor is interesting. It’s comfortable, warm, and Peter never goes hungry. In fact, Alfred just seems to appear beside him with a sandwich or a steaming bowl of soup more often than not. It’s enough to keep him fed and full. Peter gets along with the family, of course. Even Bruce, who seems distant and distracted at the best of times, completely at odds with his playboy reputation.

The only problem is his sleep and his temper. His room is too comfortable, too warm, and his bed is too soft. Peter tosses and turns more often than not, wishing that he could get away with crawling up into the nearest corner to sleep on the ceiling. He can’t, of course. Alfred keeps early hours and Peter isn’t eager to explain that particular habit if he can help it. So he tosses, turns, and grumbles in his massive, too soft bed. Eventually his perpetual frustration gives way and he starts to relax. He’s just started to drift off when he senses someone standing beside his bed.

"Hey," an unfamiliar voice says above him. "You're wearing my shirt."

Peter pauses, then slowly opens one eye. A teenager about his age is standing above him, surrounded by a gentle golden glow. The kid could be Superman’s son; he has the same dark hair, the same eyes, even the same face shape. It takes Peter a moment to realize the kid is a ghost, and when he does, he groans in frustration.

"Are you kidding me," Peter mutters.

"Wait, are we at Wayne manor?" the kid asks, looking around. "Holy shit, we are."

Peter yanks the blankets over his bead and lets out a frustrated groan. "Please shut up and let me sleep."

"What?"

"I have to go to a gala tomorrow. It's going to be awkward since it's being thrown in honor of my own death. I don’t want to go, but every time I even look at the door, Dick shows up and shoos me back to bed since I’m technically recovering from pneumonia,” Peter says from beneath the blankets. His words are muffled by the fabric. “I am tired. Please be a ghost somewhere else."

An awkward pause follows that. "I'm new to being a ghost and don't have anyone else to haunt. Could you talk to Tim for me?"

Peter freezes, then yanks the blankets down to squint at the ghost. "How do you know Tim?"

"He's my best friend."

"Incorrect, I am."

The two teens glower at one another.

"Can I slap you as a ghost?" the teen asks after a moment.

"Why would I tell you that?" Peter retorts.

The kid shrugs in response, glances around Peter’s room for a moment and then focuses on him again.

"Why am I haunting you, by the way?"

"I have the Soul Stone," Peter says. "It's like a vacuum cleaner for lost souls killed before their time."

"Whoa."

"Yeah, it sucks,” Peter says. He glances at the clock on his nightstand. Thirty minutes after midnight. He’s supposed to wake up for his suit fitting at five. Great. “Aren't there other ghosts for you to talk to?"

"I can see some, but they're kind of fuzzy and really far. They keep trying to talk to me, I think."

"Do me a favor and walk towards them or whatever light you see," Peter says, flopping over and yanking the blankets over his head.

The room falls into a peaceful silence for a long moment.

"I'm Conner, by the way," the kid says.

Conner. That name is familiar. He’s overheard Tim mention him before. Peter squints. "Wait. Tim's been looking for you."

"Can you please tell him I'm dead and that I need his help?"

Peter covers his face in his hands. This, somehow, has become even more awkward.

"No. I am not waking up my best friend to tell him his friend is dead. Not when he hasn’t been sleeping well and definitely not when I have no proof other than 'hey, the voices in my head told me your best friend is dead, his restless spirit popped up in my room last night and threatened to slap me.'” Peter says this with an exaggerated voice and even more exaggerated hand motions. He huffs and then glances at Conner. “Everyone in this place already thinks I'm one step away from a catastrophic and potentially very violent breakdown. I don’t need to end up in Arkham Asylum, thanks."

"He's in danger," Conner insists.

"Then I'll protect him."

Even in the darkness, Peter can feel Conner's disbelieving look.

"If you tell him now--"

Peter’s had enough. A renewed wave of anger sweeps over him, intermingling with his exhaustion and shortening his temper. "I said no. Go away."

He puts some strength behind his words. There’s a flash of gold, and then silence. Peter tugs down the blankets and looks around his room.

Empty. Quiet. Peaceful.

He sighs and flops back into bed. He's asleep in moments.

* * *

His peace lasts into the morning and ends the moment he steps out of the shower, pulls on his boxers, and starts to brush his teeth. He’s just decided that less than four hours of sleep is, perhaps, not ideal when Conner appears behind him in a golden flash of light.

"That was really rude, you know," Conner says behind him.

Peter startles, jumping up to cling to the ceiling out of pure instinct. He also makes a distinctly undignified noise, fumbling for his toothbrush and barely catching it in time. He stares at Conner in disbelief.

Conner stares up at him curiously. "How are you sticking to the wall like that?"

"Because I’m Spider-Man. And dude. You can’t just appear behind people like that."

"Why not?"

“First and foremost, I’m in the bathroom. That’s weird. There are rules, okay? You can haunt me literally anywhere else, but not the bathroom,” Peter says, crawling back down from the wall and adjusting his towel. "None of the other ghosts pop into the bathroom, so this is distinctly a you problem."

"None of the other ghosts are trying to save their friend's life," Conner counters. "Everyone here is in danger. He's going to hit the gala and kill his family and everyone else within reach."

"Who is?"

“Superman,” Conner says. “He killed me and now he’s going to kill everyone else.”

Peter freezes in place.

“Looks like I finally got your attention,” Conner mutters. “Come on, we need to talk to Tim--”

"No, I need a suit,” Peter says, setting down his toothbrush. “And web fluid. And, preferably, a utility belt from Batman.”

Conner stares at him. “No, we need to talk to Tim. Or Dick or Duke or literally anyone--”

Peter ignores him, walking past the ghost. He’s been working on a new suit, of course, but progress has been slow. Alfred cleans his room once a day, and Peter has been having significant trouble hiding his sewing supplies and suit material from him.

“You aren’t even listening to me, are you?”

“No, obviously not,” Peter replies. A suit. He needs a suit--

“We can get you a suit from the cave downstairs,” Conner says, annoyed.

Peter stops and turns to face Conner. “The what?”

“Follow me,” Conner says.

Peter stares after the ghost as he slips through Peter’s door and into the hallway. After a moment, he follows him down the hall towards a closet. The door opens easily. The false wall in the back of the closet slides open easier than that. Peter finds himself looking down a steep set of stairs leading into a shadowy light that smells of water, rock, and electronics. Conner’s ghost walks down the steps. Peter follows, his mind a blur.

“Bruce meant for you to find this,” Conner says idly, looking around the cave. “He doesn’t just leave entrances like this open.”

“Why would he want me to find this?” Peter asks, looking around at the cave. There’s a giant penny in the back, a massive T-rex model, the sound of rushing water and---

And suits. A lot of them. All of them belong to the Bats. Peter stops at the bottom of the stairs. Why the hell does Bruce Wayne have a cave full of Batman’s suits? He takes another look and amends that statement: Bruce has more than just Batman’s suits down here. He has Nightwing’s, Red Hood’s, and--

And his. A sleek, red and black spider suit stands at the end of the row.

“Probably because he wants you to join the family business,” Conner says dryly. “There’s your suit, now can we please go tell literally anyone else in this house--”

“What the fuck,” Red Hood says. He’s standing near a bank of computers at one end of the cave, facing Peter from behind his mask.

Peter and Red Hood stare at each other for a long moment. Conner stares at both of them.

"You really shouldn't be down here, kid," Red Hood finally says.

"Yeah, I’m just grabbing something," Peter says.

Red Hood lets out a frustrated sigh that turns into a furious growl when Peter approaches the glass case holding the spider suit. Peter opens the case and sighs, locking eyes with Conner in the reflection.

"Back me up here, man," Peter says, grabbing the suit. He puts just a tiny bit of force into his words.

Conner fades into existence, outlined in gold, standing between Peter and Red Hood.

“What the fuck,” Red Hood repeats, a bit more hysterically this time.

"He's Spider-Man," Conner says. "Jason, we need your help."

"Wait, Jason?" Peter asks, turning around as he shrugs on the suit. He squints at Red Hood, and recognition hits him. Red Hood is Jason Todd. "What the fuck?”

"Right back at you, asshole,” Red Hood retorts, storming over to him. “I thought you were dead this whole time--"

"We don't have time for this. Superman is coming to kill everyone in this house," Conner says. “He’s going to start with Lois and Jon, his family. They’re coming to the gala. They might already be here.”

Jason stops. He facepalms. He’s silent for a long moment before saying, very quietly, "Of course he is. I hate this family so fucking much."

"Save it for therapy, Red, I need your help," Peter says, pulling on the mask. The suit and mask are snug, obviously made to fit Peter when he was underfed and starving in the streets. The material stretches against the muscle mass he’s managed to build up since coming to the manor. "We don't have much time."

"Right, sure. Whatever. This might as well happen." He sounds like he’s one step away from having a breakdown. He points an accusing finger at Peter. “I cannot believe you let me think you were dead. You are such an asshole.”

“Well, when we’re done here, you and Nightwing can take turns yelling at me,” Peter replies. He tests the web shooters on his wrists. “Conner, how much time do we have?”

“Fifteen minutes, maybe,” Conner says.

“I can work with that,” Peter replies.

* * *

The plan isn’t exactly complicated; Jason is going to find Batman, Nightwing, Red Robin, Signal, and anyone else he can find to help. Peter is going to take on Superman and hold him back long enough for back up to arrive. He crawls along the outside of the manor, frustrated by the cold, the party going on inside, his lack of sleep, and the whole situation. He wants to rest. He wants to eat. He wants to throttle Jason for hiding his identity, and he wants to talk to Dick and Nightwing both. But right now, he needs to stop Superman. Conner had said Superman is being controlled, that his eyes were flashing with an unnatural blue color when he dusted Conner in his bedroom. Peter isn’t sure what to make of that.

“It means he’s been hit with an Infinity Stone,” Nick Fury says. It’s the first time he’s spoken to Peter in weeks. He sounds distant, his voice muffled. “Hawkeye had the same problem until Black Widow fixed him.”

“How’d she do that?” Peter asks.

“She hit him in the head really goddamn hard.”

“Are you telling me the Avengers saved Clint Barton using Looney Tunes logic,” Peter hisses.

“If it’s stupid, but it works...”

Fair enough. From what Peter understands, Superman is just like Captain America. There are two rules for fighting Captain America: go for the legs, and keep your distance. The general understanding is that if you’re within arm’s reach of Cap, you’ve already lost. Peter is fast, and he’s strong, and he’s clever. He managed to surprise Cap back in Germany, he might be able to do the same to Superman. Who is just like Cap.

Except he can fly. And shoot lasers out of his eyes. And, actually, he might be stronger than Cap, now that Peter thinks of it.

This might be more difficult than originally planned. Peter shifts in the shadows, suddenly glad that the strength he lost while living in the fire station has come back with a vengeance. He’ll need every ounce of it to keep Superman from hurting everyone in the gala.

It doesn’t help that Bruce Wayne keeps idly wandering out to the balcony below Peter, holding a glass of champagne. Despite the man’s focus on the distant silhouette of Gotham City, Peter has the unnerving feeling that Bruce can see him as clear as day. Which is impossible; he’s tucked in against the shadows of the manor.

“Oh, he totally knows you’re here,” Conner says.

Literally how--

“Over the city!” Conner snaps. “He’s coming in fast!”

Peter almost doesn’t catch sight of Superman in time. He’s speeding across the air, flying towards an oblivious Bruce Wayne who is, even now, turning to face the shadows Peter’s hiding within. Peter braces himself against the wall, throws himself into a deep swing and kick, flying past Bruce Wayne. Peter times it with Conner’s help. He swings for a blur of blue and red. putting as much weight and strength into the kick that he can. His heel catches Superman’s jaw, slamming him through the plate glass window leading into the ballroom with enough force to send him careening into the wall on the other side of the room. Superman lands with an annoyed, frustrated growl and pulls himself out of the shattered wood and plaster slowly, his eyes glowing red.

On anyone else, that kick would have obliterated their skull like an overripe watermelon. For Superman, it just pissed him off. Peter swings through the broken window, flinging himself up onto the ceiling. He scans the startled, terrified crowd and finds the people Conner showed him.

“Ms. Lane, get your son and get out! Now!” Peter calls out. His suit doesn’t have a voice modulator like his old one, and his voice comes out clear, Queens accent and all.

He sees Duke, Tim, and Damian Wayne snap their heads up towards him at the sound of his voice. Of course they recognize it; he lives with them. He curses, but decides to deal with that later.

“Everyone, get the hell outta here!” Peter says, swinging for Superman. If he aims this kick just right, he might be able to knock some sense back into Superman--

Superman clamps his hands around Peter’s neck the moment Peter gets within arm’s reach of the man, eyes still glowing that baleful red color. Peter knows Superman is fighting against whatever is controlling him due to two simple facts: if Superman truly wanted Peter dead, he would’ve crushed Peter’s head between his palms and obliterated what was left of him with his laser eye beams. He hasn’t. He’s still strangling Peter, but it isn’t a deathblow yet.

There’s literally no way for Peter to hit him in the head. So he does the next best thing: he kicks Superman in the stomach as hard as he can with both feet. He’s still enhanced, and his legs are the strongest parts of his body. Even a near demigod is going to feel that.

Judging by the wheezing gasp and startled look on Superman’s face, Peter’s right. Superman drops his hands away from Peter’s neck, staggering back a half step. And then he slaps Peter, apparently too winded to throw a decent punch.

In the end, it’s the slap that makes Peter’s temper snap. It’s utterly inconsequential, more insulting than painful, but it sends Peter into a red frenzy. When Superman tries to grab his neck again for another round of strangling, Peter catches both of his forearms in a crushing grip and promptly slams his forehead against the man’s nose. He does it three times in quick succession, each one more violent than the last, before bodily flinging Superman across the empty ballroom floor and through a marble pillar. The pillar crumbles like wet sand, and a much more docile Superman pulls himself out of the rubble, hand held to his head. His eyes are no longer glowing an eerie blue or simmering red. They look normal.

“You did it,” Conner starts. “Man, you’re strong--”

Peter is too lost in his rage to hear him. He sprints across the marble floor, flinging out two thick strands of webbing on the remaining pillars, yanking back against them before using them as a slingshot to fly towards Superman. The man barely realizes he’s under attack before Peter slams into him and tackles him to the ground.

He starts to punch. He’s not holding back. Each strike bounces Superman’s head off of the floor, sending a spider web of cracks crawling across the smooth stone.

“Kid, that’s enough--” Sam starts, alarmed.

“He cannot hear you,” Mantis says. “He’s too angry. I can’t calm him.”

Peter isn’t sure how many punches he lands before two sets of arms grab him and haul him away from Superman. He struggles against their grip, too startled to put real strength behind it.

“Peter, that’s enough!” Nightwing yells in his ear, struggling to haul Peter away from Superman.

Nightwing?

“Get a hold of yourself!” Jason snaps. “It’s the Pit Madness! Snap out of it!”

The---what? Peter stops fighting them, breathing hard and trembling with suppressed fury. He takes in a deep breath, letting them haul him back and away. The anger starts to drain away, leaving behind an odd hollow, exhaustion. He looks around and finds himself the center of attention. Nightwing and Red Hood each have a hold of his arms. Tim and Duke are staring at him in shock. Bruce is helping Superman stand up, but he keeps a wary eye on Peter as he does so. The rest of the guests have, wisely, run for the hills.

Peter raises his arms in surrender, then yanks off his suit mask, reaching up to touch the ring of bruises on his throat. Nightwing and Red Hood stand back from him, watching him warily.

“Okay,” Nightwing says. “I think we need to talk.”

“Yeah,” Peter replies, sitting down hard. “We do.”

Somewhere in the far corner of the Milky Way, a ship passes through stars. It moves at a speed faster than light, but not quite as fast as Tony would like.

They have enough to get home. That’s not what bothers Tony.

It’s the fact that Carol--apparently a new recruit for the Avengers--left before he could ask her any important questions and hasn’t come back yet. She simply appeared in front of the ship, glowing like the sun and hauling two massive crates along behind her, said she was going to make sure no one was following them, and then left.

And hasn’t been back since.

It’s been weeks. Maybe months. He can’t tell; everything looks the same inside this ship. It’s like being in an isolation cell in prison. Except that he has Blue nearby; not a huge talker, that one, but she’s warming up to his neurotic tendencies. Which is a good thing; if she takes a dislike to him, she could easily fling him out of the airlock. Fortunately, he’s managed to charm her, though God alone only knows how.

He grabs a tasteless meal bar from the supplies Carol brought them and wanders over to the cockpit. Blue--Nebula--looks up at him as he approaches and offers a slight nod of greeting.

“Any luck?” he asks.

“No,” she replies. “All of the fueling platforms within range are derelict. I suspect most of them exploded when the Snap occurred since there was no one around to maintain safety protocols. Space fuel under pressure is extremely volatile.”

Well. That makes sense, but it’s still disappointing. “So, no shortcuts home, huh?”

“No. We do have enough standard fuel to make the trip.”

“And how long will that take?”

“I’m unfamiliar with your solar system and the Benatar does not have the astrography calculations for---”

He recognizes that urge to over explain. Another hot coal of fury is added to the simmering rage he holds for Thanos. Tony raises his hand. “Ballpark it for me.”

Fortunately, she’s (somehow) familiar with that phrase. She simplifies her response: “We’ll arrive within the next six Earth months.”

Tony sighs, waving a hand over one of the consoles to bring up a map of the galaxy. It’s not news he wanted to hear, but it’s the news he’s got. Six more months of wondering if anyone is still left alive on Earth. Thanos snapped away half of the universe; that doesn’t necessarily mean half of all life on every single planet. He could have easily wiped out entire planets and left others intact. It’s all up to blind luck and chance.

“Six months of freeze dried potatoes and beef paste it is, then,” Tony says, idly tracing out theoretical paths through the stars. None of them are any quicker than the path Nebula chose for them, but he’s nosy and bored and needs to fidget in a semi-productive way. “Which is about the only palatable food left in that crate.”

“I enjoy the ice cream,” Nebula says.

“You can have all of mine, then.”

Nebula perks up slightly. She doesn’t give him suspicious side long looks when he gives her something anymore, but seeing her excitement is almost worse in some ways. He resolves to take her by one of the good ice cream places in New York when they get back. There’s one that Peter dragged him to once that--

He shuts that thought down before it can fully take hold and focuses on the map in front of him instead. He traces out a path past a few binary star systems, and a massive black hole.

“What if we--” he starts.

A flash of golden light appears in front of the ship, bright enough to shoot blades of light through the metal shutters over the cockpit windows and illuminate the cockpit. Tony has a brief moment of panic that resolves into hope (Carol arrived in much the same way, after all) and then utter confusion.

The light fades. Something hits the front of the ship with a hard, echoing thwump. For a moment, he and Nebula stare at each other before she cautiously raises the metal shutter over the window in front of her and peers through it. The angle is such that Tony can’t see what she’s seeing.

“What did you hit?” he asks.

“A child.”

Tony stares at her. “You...ran over a kid? In space?”

“Yes.”

“How?”

She checks her console. “At top speed. He is remarkably intact.”

Tony moves over to her seat and looks over her shoulder. And stares.

Pressed against their window is the body of a teenager. A huge teenager--one that looks like he could rival Cap for size and muscle alone--but a regular human teenager nonetheless. He’s wearing sneakers, jeans, and a black shirt with a red S across the chest. His face, arms, and--well, every bit of exposed skin is black and blue from bruises. Fresh ones from the look of it, too. It looks like someone took a tire iron to the kid before flinging him out into space.

“What the fu--”

The kid’s eyes snap open. He gasps, clutching at his throat. Tony forgets his confusion and summons his suit. It’s not entirely spaceworthy at the moment, but it should be good for a quick EVA. The nanites roll out and over his skin, sealing up tight just as he floats into space and along the outside of the ship. For a moment, the old fear and phobia hits him, and he has to fight off distant memories of the Battle of New York as he reaches out and grabs the kid. By the time he wrestles the kid inside, the worst of the fear is gone.

The kid gasps, coughs, and groans in pain. And Tony is sure that he’s not fully human, despite how he looks. Humans pass out in seconds in space; the lack of oxygen and pressure plays merry hell on organs meant to survive in Earth’s gravity. The kid is somehow still conscious.

“Easy, kid, take it slow,” Tony says, drawing the suit back before kneeling down beside the kid.

“Where--” the kid starts, his voice raspy and confused.

“Space. The far side of it, actually. If one wanted to be charitable, you could almost call it the ass end of space, in fact,” Tony says. He offers the kid a hand up. “I’m Tony. The pilot up front is Nebula. What’s your name?”

“Conner,” the kid says, taking Tony’s hand. He doesn’t need help to get back onto his own feet, but he accepts the offered hand anyway and stands on his own two feet. “Conner Kent.”

“Well, Conner, you’re lucky we ran you over. How’d you end up here?”

If there’s another ship nearby, one hostile enough to beat the shit out of a teenager before flinging him into the cold void of space, then Tony would like to know that. First, so he can return the favor on whoever hurt this guy, and second, so he can steal their fuel supplies.

“There was--a fight,” Conner says haltingly, as if trying to piece together his own memories. “I was in Gotham.”

“Is that a ship?” Tony asks.

Conner shakes his head. “A city. On Earth.”

“You know, that’s weird, seeing as I’m from Earth and have absolutely no idea what you’re talking about. What was happening in Gotham?”

“A fight. A big fight--it’d have to be big if the Bats were calling for help. Red Robin called out to me for help. Some new hero had gone insane. They needed help containing him,” Conner says. He winces. “He was stronger than we were ready for. Way stronger.”

Tony, well and truly lost, decides to just roll with this. “I’m guessing that new guy had super strength, given your bruises.”

“God, does he ever,” Conner mutters, rubbing the back of his neck. “And he could stick to things, too. Crawl or run up walls like gravity doesn’t apply to him. That’s not a huge deal, but it is when he can duck into a crevice somewhere and blind you with webs.”

Tony goes very, very still. “Webs.”

“Yeah,” Conner says. He tugs at a splotch of half frozen webbing on his sleeve, making a face. “I really hope this stuff doesn’t come out of that guy.” He sighs. “The new guy threw a bus at me--an empty one, thank god--and then he hit me with a glob of that webbing before jumping me. The weirdest part--before I ended up here anyway--was that he was begging for help the entire time. Have you ever been beaten up by someone asking for help?”

“No, no, I have not,” Tony says stiffly. “What happened after that?”

“A big orange flash, some guy with a goatee and a cape appeared in front of me and said, ‘I’m sorry, I have to send you to another dimension. I’m doing this to save your life. When you meet the man in the metal suit, tell him everything’ and then I ended up plastered to the front of your ship,” Conner says, shrugging. He pauses. “I guess you’re the guy with the metal suit.”

Dr. Strange is still alive, then. Or alive enough to throw teenagers through portals. Tony’s mind is going a mile a minute. “Yeah, that’s me. Did you catch the name of the guy who beat you up? The one with the webs?”

It’s obvious, but he wants to be sure.

“Nightwing and Red Robin called him Spider-Man,” Conner says.

Tony lets out an explosive breath, closes his eyes, and then opens them again, focusing on Conner. “Once you’re rested, we’re going to discuss all of that again. Okay?”

Which is remarkably patient for him. Tony wants to grill this kid nonstop for every detail of this other dimension. He wants to know how Strange is alive. He wants to know if this Spider-Man is his Spider-Man or just another universe’s version of him. He wants to know everything.

But Conner is hurt, confused, and surprisingly resistant to explosive decompression. He probably needs to rest.

Hell, the kid was just literally shot out of the only reality he’s ever known and ended up in an entirely different one. He’s probably going to have some reaction to that, too. Tony would be a mess, personally. More of a mess, at least.

“Yeah. Yeah, sure,” Conner says, rubbing his eyes.

When Tony wakes up, it’s to the sound of strange machines, rattling chains, and the sharp, arrogant tones of Ebony Maw giving orders. It takes him a moment to put together the chain of events that’s yanked him into this situation and when he does, he fights back a curse. The ship had been taken, yanked inside another ship they hadn’t seen on their sensors. He and Nebula had fled the ship, ready to do battle--and come face to face with an entire army of outriders. All things being equal, they had given it their all, but the outcome was inevitable: a flock of the damn things separated him from Nebula and tackled him straight into a portal and here.

Wherever here is. It’s Earth, he knows that much. The few stars he can see from the spire look the same, at least. The fact that he can occasionally hear distant police sirens, gunshots, and traffic also adds weight to that theory. No Stark satellite network though; he would’ve seen one or two crossing the sky by now. They might have been lost to the invasion, or simply fallen out of the sky when half his workforce collapsed into dust and ash.

So he’s in a different place, alone, and being held prisoner by the Black Order.

He is, to put it lightly, screwed.

He’s chained up inside some fucked up tower in the middle of a city he doesn’t know, unable to reach the arc reactor hidden beneath his shirt. Worse, he’s in the custody of the Black Order. Ebony Maw is alive (somehow), apparently in the middle of organizing an invasion. He stands in the middle of the spire, glowering down at a computer console.

Peter’s Iron Spider suit sits on the floor behind him, battered and scuffed, but still whole from what Tony can see. He wants to get to that suit badly; Nebula had left it behind on Titan, more worried about Tony’s fatal wound than any souvenirs from their battle against her father. Tony had resolved to go back to Titan for it, but it looks like Ebony Maw got to it first. Jackass.

“Mr. Stark,” an unfamiliar voice says beside him. There’s a strain to it, a grogginess that Tony knows all too well. The guy either has a concussion or a bruised jaw. Possibly both.

“I see my reputation precedes me,” Tony says, his voice hoarse until he clears his throat. He turns to face the new guy and winces. “They did a number on you, pal.”

The man is in a black and blue super suit, one that almost looks like something Tony would design himself. There are a few differences here and there, things that tug at the edges of his memory before he shakes it off. What does catch his eye is the Avengers A stenciled on his shoulder.

“You could say that,” the man says, grunting in pain. Bruises cover his face and neck, fresh and old alike. “Fancy meeting you here.”

He sounds annoyed. As if they’ve already met.

One of Cap’s people, then.

Great.

“You know me,” Tony says, eyes roaming the interior of the spire with an increasing amount of frustration. Magic. He never liked magic. Nuclear radiation kills you dead, but at least it has rules. Magic functions on fairy farts, from what Tony can tell. No hard rules, nothing to contain the power. That’s always rubbed him the wrong way. “Always looking for a new experience or three. What’s your name?”

“Nightwing.”

“Cool name. Way better than Hawkeye. I’m starting to wonder about Cap’s obsession with bird people, though.”

That earns him a confused look. “Cap?”

Tony gives him one right back. “Yeah. Captain America? You know, the ultimate boy scout? Sanctimonious asshole with the blue supersuit? Carries a shield around with a giant star on it? Or he used to, anyway.”

“Never met him,” Nightwing says, an odd tone to his voice. “I’ve seen someone draw a few pictures of him though.”

“Yeah, well, you aren’t missing much,” Tony replies.

“Why do they have you strung up like this?” Nightwing asks.

Tony lets out a huff. “Because I broke their portal when I went through it and they’re trying to get me to fix it.”

“They don’t know how their own machines work?” Nightwing asks, raising an eyebrow.

“Well, the tall guy in the middle of the room, Ebony Maw, used to know. Until I killed him. Turns out there are side effects to being killed.”

Nightwing peers at Ebony Maw. “Looks like he got better.”

“Yeah, next time I’ll take Peter’s suggestion and add ‘blow a hole in his goddamn head’ to the last step,” Tony mutters. Nightwing turns a sharp glance his way and he shrugs. “Nevermind. Not important.”

He drops his voice when he sees a swarm of winged outriders fly down the top of the spire, heading towards Tony and Nightwing. “Shit. They brought kids.”

Nightwing looks up and sucks in a breath, growing tense inside the chains that are binding him. The outriders bring three teenage boys over to their little corner, tossing all three to the magical chains dangling around them. Each chain shoots out and rapidly cocoons one of the boys. Two fight back, nearly breaking free before being yanked back into their half formed cocoons: a black haired kid with blue eyes that carries a runner’s build beneath an extremely well tailored suit and a dark skinned boy with a bright yellow jacket over motorcycle riding leathers. The last one doesn’t even flinch: the chains capture him, leaving him to hang inside the cocoon, almost bonelessly. There’s something oddly familiar about that one.

Nightwing clenches his jaw. The other two boys curse and struggle. The kid in the yellow jacket manages a vicious kick to one of the outriders before it flies off, sending him into a dangling twirl that makes him turn slowly on the chain. The other boy, the one in the suit, is staring at Tony. Hard.

“You all right?” Tony asks.

“I’m fine,” the kid says, staring at him closely. It’s a hard stare, one full of suspicion, and Tony is a little unnerved by the intensity behind it. “Duke?”

“Yeah, I’m good, Tim,” the kid in yellow says, grumbling. “They were waiting for me--”

He finally turns all the way around and sees Tony. His eyes go wide and he stumbles to a stop mid sentence before glancing over at the third kid. Or, actually, around the other kid. Tony follows his gaze and wonders what the hell he’s seeing. And hearing. Duke tilts his head, as if he’s listening to something that isn’t there. Maybe he’s enhanced? He might be able to hear Ebony Maw from here if that’s the case.

The third kid shifts in his chains, groaning as he lifts his head up. He coughs, and mutters, “Wha--”

Tony sucks in a breath. That voice is entirely too familiar, and brings with it a wave of memories he isn’t ready to confront just yet. A trick? Or just bad luck. Sometimes people have similar voices--

“Tony?” the kid says, his voice wavering. “Is that really you?”

“How do you know me?” Tony asks.

“It’s me,” the kid says. And it’s almost convincing. Almost. “It’s Peter.”

“You aren’t him,” Tony says, voice tight. “This is a trick. That’s all.”

“No, really--”

“I saw Peter die, in front of me, in my arms. I watched him flake apart into dust. Hell, I still have the shirt that’s covered in what’s left of his body, because that’s all I can give his family. You aren’t Peter Parker. You’re something made up to look like him,” Tony says flatly. He glances at the kid and scoffs. “They didn’t even get his eyes right. And what’s with the dyed hair? The kid wouldn’t do that. Drop the act, asshole.”

Not-Peter looks wounded and frustrated, grinding his teeth as if he’s fighting back a sudden surge of rage. Add that to the list of things that don’t quite fit. Peter has a temper, but he doesn’t switch from an eager explanation to tooth grinding rage like the fucking Hulk just because someone gets snappy with him. Typically, there’s a moment or two of a kicked puppy look before the anger swells up.

“You were saying, Bird Boy?”

“Nightwing,” Nightwing corrects, his tone odd, as if he’s puzzling through something. He keeps glancing at Not-Peter. “How long have you been here?”

“Since the storm started,” Tony says in a huff. “Got sucked into a portal and spat out in the middle of all of this. This isn’t the worst torture chamber I’ve been chained up in, but it’s bordering on the most boring.”

Nightwing shoots Not-Peter a look. The other kid, Tim, does the same. Not-Peter fidgets inside his chain prison, something close to a guilty expression crossing his features. He really does look like Peter--in the face, at least. He’s too skinny otherwise, and the hair and eyes are obviously wrong. As far as fakes go, it’s a pretty half assed attempt.

“I thought I saw you at a parent teacher conference,” Tim says.

Tony gives him a baffled look. “What?”

Tim shoots Not-Peter a look.

Not-Peter shrugs. “Magic.”

“Duke saw a man with two faces at the school before the attack,” Tim says, half under his breath. He glances at Nightwing. The two share some kind of unspoken conversation between each other--it’s downright eerie, really. Tony’s only ever seen that kind of thing play out between Clint and Nat. “That wasn’t actually Tony Stark, was it?”

“No, it wasn’t,” Not-Peter admits, taking in a deep breath and slowly gaining control of himself again. “It was--it was someone else doing me a favor.” He pauses, scrunches up his face and adds, “Kind of. It’s complicated. They were one of my, uh, ghosts.”

“And if you were really the kid, you’d know Nat’s first rule for lying: ‘keep it simple, stupid.’ No one’s gonna buy that ghost line,” Tony says. Not-Peter fights back another swell of rage and Tony scoffs. “Yeah, calm it down, Hulk Junior.”

A voice suddenly shouts near Tony’s ear, almost as clear as day, frustration laced across every syllable: “Man, will you shut the hell up and listen?”

Tony starts, glancing over his shoulder as much as he can. He sees nothing but brick and cement, twisted out of place, but empty of any living soul. He frowns, twisting around to look over his other shoulder. Still nothing.

“Did...anyone else hear that?” Tony asks.

“That was Sam,” Duke says. “He’s pretty annoyed with you right now. So are the rest of Peter’s ghosts.”

Tony frowns at him, fighting off confusion, frustration, and a rapidly growing headache. He wants to spout off some sharp retort about the existence of ghosts, but he can’t quite shake off an eerie feeling of being watched by someone behind him. That voice was definitely Sam Wilson’s. A trick, maybe? Ebony Maw might have someone like Wanda on his team--

“What do I have to do to prove it to you?” Not-Peter says, frustration threading his words.

“Not sure that you can,” Tony quips, still glancing behind himself warily.

Not-Peter seethes, looking around the spire. In the middle of the room, the Black Order is talking amongst themselves, plotting out their upcoming invasion. Tony strains his hearing, trying to listen in. He misses his suit; his hearing isn’t what used to be; years of head pounding rock, loud parties, and then flying through the upper atmosphere have done a number on that particular sense. Usually FRIDAY can help, but well--

She’s trapped both inside the Iron Spider across the room from him and in the arc reactor pressed against the center of his chest. Tony shifts inside his chain prison, gradually pulling his hand a bit closer to the arc reactor. If he can just get his hand over another few inches--

“That one. The one in yellow,” Ebony Maw says, pointing at the little group, and Duke in particular. “He isn’t like the others. We can use him--”

“Did you really have to go and do this on a Friday?” Not-Peter calls out, interrupting him. His focus is set on the center platform, and the Iron Spider pod in particular.

The Iron Spider’s case flashes to life, the standard blue-white of all Stark technology flashes twice. Once to acknowledge Peter’s voice, and once to show readiness for further commands from its user. Tony put FRIDAY into that suit; even a perfect mimic can’t fool her. She’s dialed in on Peter’s DNA. She won’t activate for anyone but Peter and Tony.

It is Peter.

Shit.

Tony snaps his head back to Peter, his heart pounding in his ears. “Peter?”

“You,” Ebony Maw says, focused on Peter now instead of Duke. “You should be dead.”

Ebony Maw makes a sharp motion with his hand, yanking Peter down towards his platform. The kid gives Tony a panicked, guilty look that is so painfully Peter Parker that Tony feels his stomach drop. The expression disappears once he gets closer to Ebony Maw, replaced by false bravado that Tony can see right through.

There’s a roaring sound in Tony’s ears, muffling Peter’s entirely too confident words and Ebony Maw’s sharp, impatient replies. When one of the eerily glowing green vats rises, fills with swirling black dust, and births out a half mad outrider, Tony begins to piece things together himself. When Peter shrinks back from the vat, his eyes becoming guarded and terrified, he makes the connections. He feels himself go pale and becomes dizzy, sees Nightwing clench his jaw tighter.

That is an ugly way to come back to life.

Horror gives way to fury, cold and sharp. He can work with that.

“Nightwing,” he says. “On the count of three, I’m going to break out of these chains and go help the kid. Will you help me?”

“Yes,” Nightwing says. He says it so quickly that Tony can barely finish his sentence. Tony’s regard for the hero rachets up a tiny bit.

“Good. One, two--” He wrenches his hand over, ignoring the sharp pain in his shoulder when he does so. He presses his palm against the arc reactor, and feels the nanobots swarm out to build his suit, encasing him in the strongest and most advanced suit he’s ever made. When the helmet forms, FRIDAY greets him with the five custom HUDs he needs to pilot the suit. His voice comes out with the distinctive Iron Man echo.

“Three.”
